awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Towards Secure Decision Making in Spectrum and Energy Efficient IoT Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet-of-Things (IoT) has recently emerged as a powerful new paradigm for future generations of wireless networks. In IoT, a wide variety of devices, such as body sensors, implants, animal biochip transponders, electric clams in coastal waters, vehicular sensors, sensors for environmental/food/pathogen monitoring, and devices in disaster relief operations, are connected to the Internet via wireless interfaces. Connecting this myriad of mobile devices to the Internet could potentially lead to a broad range of innovative network applications. However, unique technical challenges for IoT, such as massive connectivity, security vulnerability and energy sustainability, among others, need to be addressed before such potentials can be fully fulfilled. 

This project aims to develop a robust and secure framework for wireless function computing to specifically address challenges in IoT applications. The enabling characteristic of this framework is that in many IoT applications, instead of recovering the full data collected by various devices and transmitted over the network, the goal of the networked functional computing is to assist certain decision making, for which the decision makers only need to compute a function of these distributed data.  The main idea of this project is to develop secure and spectrum/energy efficient protocols that enable the decision maker to compute functions of interest without first recovering the full data from sensing devices. Thus, instead of acting as mere data pipes, wireless links become an integral part of the smart decision process in IoT applications.  Successful execution of this project will make substantial contributions to both practical applications and theory development. On the application level, this project has the potential to substantially improve the spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency and robustness to active attacks for future IoT networks. On the theory side, this project will develop low-complexity efficient and robust function computing algorithms that enable IoT applications to make timely and accurate decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project addresses some critical and emerging challenges in future generations of wireless communication networks to serve the needs of the widespread Internet of Things (IoT) applications. Unlike existing cellular networks, IoT marks a paradigm shift in future generations of wireless networks by supporting a wide variety of low power devices, including body sensors, implants, animal biochip transponders, vehicular sensors, sensors for environmental/food/pathogen monitoring. To connect a myriad of small and mobile devices to the Internet could stimulate a broad range of innovative network applications and present unique technical challenges. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a robust and secure wireless function computing framework to specifically address spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency, and security issues in wireless networks for IoT applications. The underlying principle of our framework is that in many IoT applications, instead of recovering the full data observed by various devices, the role of wireless networks is to assist certain decision-making based on function computation of distributed data. Such IoT devices can send all their raw data to the decision maker, which can then compute the function of interest. However, this approach will incur a tremendous overhead since most of the raw data are discarded after the functions of interest are computed, and require more costly spectrum/energy. This project develops secure and spectrum/energy efficient protocols that enable the decision maker to compute functions of interest without first recovering the full data from sensing devices. Thus, instead of being treated as mere data pipes, wireless links become an integral part of the smart decision process in IoT applications. The research findings allow future network designers to improve the spectrum and energy efficiency and to reduce decision delays, leading to new system designs, new tools, and results that can impact other science and engineering fields.

One major project finding arises from investigating IoT decision making with privacy and secrecy constraints. The decision maker aims to compute a function of data stored at IoT devices subject to a preset distortion level while minimizing data privacy leakage. We investigated tradeoffs among message rates, private information leakage, equivocation, and distortion to develop robust distributed optimization algorithms for IoT systems. In another important finding, we studied end-to-end training and learning of networked artificial intelligence (AI) systems. Multimedia-based detection and classification in a networked environment are among the top AI applications. We developed an end-to-end deep learning framework to achieve faster and more accurate classification by directly training a deep learning image classifier using wavelet transform coefficients from the popular JPEG-2000 compression by skipping image reconstruction. The proposed solution is well suited for joint compression and cloud-based image or video classification over limited network bandwidth. Another project outcome relates to exploration of hidden data features from IoT sensing data that often exhibit complex structures that pose challenges to traditional tools. Extending graph signal processing, we developed new tools in hypergraph signal processing (HGSP) to represent and capture high-order relationships of data samples common in many IoT applications. In the specific application of 3D point cloud data, we proposed a hypergraph-based new point cloud model that is amenable to efficient analysis and processing. We established an analytical connection between hypergraph spectrum and structural features. We further evaluate the efficacy of hypergraph spectrum estimation in two common applications of sampling and denoising of point clouds for which we provide specific hypergraph filter design and spectral properties. We also developed a new point-cloud segmentation method.  In an effort to simplify IoT wireless access, we designed a new low complexity framework to enable low-latency sensor transmission for a decision server to coordinate measurement sensors for accurate event detection through over-the-air aggregation of sensor data over a multiple-access channel. We formulate several collaborative over-the-air event detection problems under different practical protocols for collaborative learning and decision making. These research findings are expected to have a significant broad impact on a wide range of wireless applications including high mobility, IoT, and distributed services.
